column10: COMMENTS (either add comments here or using the comment function in a given cell. Do not write in the cell itself!)

column39: How often are new forecasts produced (in days)
column41: Model training period mentioned in paper? (y/n)

column60: Paper states that forecast was evaluated (y/n)
column61: Forecast evaluation results reported in paper (y/n)
column62: List all skill metrics used (e.g. R2, RMSE, bias, MAE)
column63: Is forecast performance assessed at multiple forecast horizons (results must be reported in paper/supplimental info)? (y/n)
column64: How many forecasting cycles are evaluated/assessed, with the results reported in the paper? (PLEASE READ NOTES HERE)
column65: How many total forecasting cycles are included for that variable in this paper (both those that are evaluated and those that are not)
column66: Maximum forecast horizon such that the forecast is better than the null model (out of any models used). Provide answer in days
column68: Maximum driver latency (latency of the driver with the longest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column69: Minimum driver latency (latency of the driver with the shortest latency). If not specified write "UNK". Provide answer in days
column70: Temporal coverage of data used to create this forecasting paper (in days; your best guess is fine here)
column71: Is new data (driver and/or observations) available to the model in real time (<24 hours from collection) without any manual effort when the system is working as intended? (y/n)
column73: Repository in which forecasts are archived
column74: Paper specifies that driver data are publicly available to reproduce the forecasts (according to the paper)
column77: Partnership w/ stakeholder in forecast development mentioned in paper (y/n)
column78: Forecast being used by stakeholder according to paper (y/n)

column3: Temporal dynamics and drivers of landscape-level spread by emerald ash borer
column4: Ward, SF; Fei, SL; Liebhold, AM
column12: The authors are interested in predicting invasion of wood boring beetles. Although their modeling approach appears to take spatial heterogeneity into account, from what I can tell they are simply using distance between certain counties as predictors. The are predicting risk of invasion, invasion of adjoining counties, and radial range expansion
column20: effective range radius, invasion, risk of invasion
column24: effective range: segmented regression, invasion: GAM (generalized additive model), risk of invasion: cox proportional hazards

column3: USING WEATHER RECORDS WITH A FORAGE PRODUCTION-MODEL TO FORECAST RANGE FORAGE PRODUCTION
column4: WIGHT, JR; HANSON, CL; WHITMER, D
column12: A physically based forage yield model is used to predict yield index. The model is initialized at the start of the growing season (April 1) and predicts up to the end of the growing season (July 15) and is updated on May 1, June 1, July 1. Different historical temperature values from the dates are used as initializations for April 1, and then averages are taken (think of it as an ensemble). When the model is updated in the later months, observed values are used from April 1 - current.

column3: How far might medium-term weather forecasts improve nitrogen fertiliser use and benefit arable farming in the England and Wales?
column4: Dailey, AG; Smith, JU; Whitmore, AP
column8: this one is tricky, it uses weather forecasts to drive a model which predicts N availability which then advises how much N fertilizer to apply?
column9: yes forecast, also has a management application (see ww comment), but figure shows forecasted N offtake under different scenarios (forecast accuracy/duration)

column3: Forecasting Cameraria ohridella invasion dynamics in recently invaded countries: from validation to prediction
column4: Gilbert, M; Guichard, S; Freise, J; Gregoire, JC; Heitland, W; Straw, N; Tilbury, C; Augustin, S
column12: Really cool idea. They are forecasting the adundance of Cameraria (an invasive moth) in France using a spatial simulation model with a logistic regression to predict presence/absence. The model was created for Germany, but is shown to capture the dynamics of invasions in France as well. It is subseuqently used to forecast the distribution in the UK
column24: logistic regression is used to determine presence / absence in specific locations. then kriging (gaussian process) is used to impute spatially. then a monte carlo simulation model following probabilistic rules is run
column36: diffusion is the null model i believe
